courses.name: Orientation
courses.description: This course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, College of Education programs and expectations and career options. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Orientation: Art Education
courses.description: This course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, College of Education programs and expectations and career options, emphasizing Art Education.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Orientation
courses.description: The course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, College of Education programs, expectations and career options, emphasizing Social Studies education.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Orientation: Math Education
courses.description: This course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, College of Education programs and expectations and career options, emphasizing Math Education.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Orientation: Middle School Education
courses.description: This course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, College of Education programs and expectations and career options, emphasizing Middle School Education.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Learning Strategies for College Students
courses.description: Students' learning strategies are assessed, and their needs are given greatest emphasis. Learning through reading and listening are given major consideration as are the corollary skills of vocabulary expansion, studying and note taking.

courses.name: Orientation: Science Education
courses.description: This course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, College of Education programs and expectations and career options, emphasizing Science Education.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Orientation: Special Education
courses.description: This course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, College of Education programs and expectations and career options, emphasizing Special Education.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Orientation
courses.description: This course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, College of Education programs, expectations and career options, emphasizing English/Language Arts education.  Graded on S/U only.

courses.name: Orientation
courses.description: The course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, College of Education programs, expectations and career options, emphasizing Early Childhood education.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Orientation
courses.description: The course familiarizes and orients students with MU resources, college of Education programs, expectations and career options, emphasizing Elementary Education.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: First Aid
courses.description: Study of the theory and practice of first aid procedures. Certification available.

courses.name: Scuba Theory
courses.description: The curriculum of the class includes bio-physics, hydrostatic pressures, physiology, fundamentals of compressed gases, environmental conditions, mechanics, first aid as it relates to diving, and planning speciality dives such as decompression, night, cave, ice, salvage and wreck diving.

courses.name: Inquiring into Schools, Community and Society I
courses.description: This course focuses on schooling in American society, the school community, the school culture and students' lives and identities. Studied are the political, cultural, and economic conditions of the schools.

courses.name: Inquiry into Schools, Community and Society: Field
courses.description: This field experience course supports the Inquiring into Schools, Community and Society (ISCS), component of Phase I. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: School Health and Student Wellbeing
courses.description: This course will explore and analyze the critical role schools and teachers play to address students' physical, social, and emotional wellbeing. Research indicates that a healthy school environment can improve both academic and social outcomes. Focus areas include school safety, nutrition policy and health education.

courses.name: Aiding: Nursery/Day Care Programs
courses.description: Instructionally related duties in the preschool classroom during semesters and summer. Student works 30 hours with supervision for each credit.

courses.name: Aiding: Kindergarten
courses.description: Instructionally related activities in kindergarten classroom during semesters and summers. Student works 30 hours with supervision for each credit. Graded on an S/U basis only.

courses.name: Aiding: Primary Grades
courses.description: Instructionally related activities in primary grades. Student works 30 hours with supervision for each credit. Graded on an S/U basis only.

courses.name: Aiding: Intermediate Grades
courses.description: Instructionally related activities in intermediate grade classrooms. Student works 30 hours with supervision for each credit. Graded on an S/U basis only.

courses.name: Aiding: Secondary Schools
courses.description: Instructionally related clinical/administrative and monitorial activities in the secondary classroom during semesters and summer. Student works 30 hours with supervision for each credit. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Student Teaching
courses.description: Hours, credit must be arranged with director of student teaching. Must apply during February for following year.
courses.hours: 1-99Recommended: special methods courses in area of specialization

courses.name: Problems in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Studies professional programs and issues in health or physical education.

courses.name: Problems in Curriculum and Instruction - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Studies professional programs and issues in health or physical education.

courses.name: Assessment and Family Collaboration in Early Childhood Education
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7091). Strategies for effectively observing and assessing young children and strategies for building positive family and community relationships, which support children's development and learning.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required (enrollment limited to students admitted to Phase II)

courses.name: Working with Infants and Toddlers
courses.description: Experience working with children aged 6 weeks to 2 1/2 years and their families. Opportunity to apply theories of cognitive, language, and social development.

courses.name: Early Childhood Education Literacy Methods & Assessment I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7120). Strategies for assessing and supporting young children's literacy development. Graded on A-F basis only.   Recommended:  admittance to College of Education required and co enrollment of LTC 4210 and LTC 4124: K-3 Field Experience.

courses.name: Early Childhood Education Literacy Methods & Assessment I - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7120). Strategies for assessing and supporting young children's literacy development. Graded on A-F basis only.   Recommended:  admittance to College of Education required and co enrollment of LTC 4210 and LTC 4124: K-3 Field Experience.

courses.name: Emergent and Developing Literacy Early Childhood Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4120 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4120 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching and Learning Math, Science and Social Studies w/ Young Children
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7130). Strategies for assessing and supporting young children's math, science and social studies learning. Includes strategies for home-school collaboration. Must take concurrently with K-3 field experience.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching & Learning Math, Sci & Soc Studies w/Young Children Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4130 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4130 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Curriculum, Theory and Classroom Management in Early Childhood Education
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7140). Reflection on the relationship of theory and practice in ECE. Consideration of various topics including historical influences on early childhood curriculum, models of early childhood curriculum, classroom management, and individualizing curriculum.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required (enrollment limited to students who have completed the first two semesters of Phase II)

courses.name: Curriculum, Theory and Classroom Management in Early Childhood Education - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7140). Reflection on the relationship of theory and practice in ECE. Consideration of various topics including historical influences on early childhood curriculum, models of early childhood curriculum, classroom management, and individualizing curriculum.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required (enrollment limited to students who have completed the first two semesters of Phase II)

courses.name: Early Childhood Education Literacy Teaching Methods and Assessment II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7150).  Advanced strategies for assessing and supporting young children's literacy development.
courses.recommendation: LTC 4120 or LTC 7120, LTC 4124 K-3 Field experience and admittance to the ECE certification program in Phase II of the College of Education required

courses.name: Motor Development in Young Children
courses.description: For Early Childhood majors. Study of young children's motor development.

courses.name: Program Management & Environmental Organization in PreKindergarten
courses.description: Strategies for working with children aged 2-6 and their families. Emphasis on planning and implementing developmentally appropriate practice, designing effective learning environments, and managing programs.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required (enrollment limited to students admitted to Phase II, and completion of first 2 semesters of Phase II)

courses.name: Elementary Education Field Experience I
courses.description: Seminars and diverse 1-5 grade classroom experience focus is on the learner and learning in the elementary school. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Young Children's Emergent Language
courses.description: For Early Childhood and Elementary Education majors. Study of young children's language development and implications for teachers.

courses.name: Children's Language and Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7210). For Early Childhood Education majors. Examines children's oral language development and surveys the field of children's literature for children ages birth to eight.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Literacy Assessment and Development
courses.description: Focus is on the development, assessment, and instruction of reading and writing motivations, skills, and strategies of diverse learners with emphasis on data interpretation and instruction.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Emergent Literacy
courses.description: Emergent reading. Instructional methods, diagnostic procedures, and materials appropriate for learners in elementary grades 1-3.

courses.name: Contexts and Methods for Elementary Reading Instruction
courses.description: Students will closely explore the different contexts, methods, and materials for reading instruction in diverse settings. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Contexts and Methods for Writing Instruction
courses.description: This course explores contexts and methods for writing instruction, with a focus on writing development, writing across the content, and multimodel and multilingual composition. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Contexts and Methods for Writing Instruction - Writing Intensive
courses.description: This course explores contexts and methods for writing instruction, with a focus on writing development, writing across the content, and multimodel and multilingual composition. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Art for Children
courses.description: This course focuses on appropriate teaching methods and strategies for teaching art (studio, art history, aesthetic, and criticism), artistic development of children, and curriculum, instructional, and organization strategies for the art classroom.

courses.name: Diverse Literature for Children and Youth
courses.description: Reading and discussion of diverse literature within a wide variety of genres will allow students to explore issues of diversity as related to elementary instruction. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Diverse Literature for Children and Youth - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Reading and discussion of diverse literature within a wide variety of genres will allow students to explore issues of diversity as related to elementary instruction. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Music for Children
courses.description: Preparation of early childhood and elementary education students with the skills, knowledge, and philosophical foundations necessary to integrate music into the early childhood and elementary curricula.
courses.recommendation: MUSIC_NM 1608, MUSIC_NM 1612, MUSIC_NM 1618 or competency test; Admittance to Phase II

courses.name: Elementary Social Studies
courses.description: To develop knowledge of social studies and the skills to teach social studies in the elementary school. The course is designed to provide the student with the skills to plan, implement, and evaluate both the teaching and learning processes for the elementary social studies classroom.

courses.name: Teaching Science in Elementary Schools
courses.description: Concepts, materials, methods in the elementary school program.

courses.name: Elementary Education Field Experience II
courses.description: Seminars and diverse 1-5 grade classroom experiences focus is on the teacher and instruction in the elementary school. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Learning and Teaching Number and Operation in the Elementary School
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to (a) develop a deeper understanding of number and operation, (b) connect the mathematical knowledge of number as described in (a) to the learning and teaching of number in elementary school.

courses.name: Learning and Teaching Geometry in the Elementary School
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to (a) develop a deeper understanding of geometry and measurement, (b) critically examine content and issues of the complexities in teaching and learning fundamental concepts of geometry and measurement in elementary schools.

courses.name: Middle School Social Studies I
courses.description: Curriculum decision making, instructional planning, techniques and strategies, materials selection, approaches to assessment in middle level social studies, all based upon early adolescent growth and development principles.

courses.name: Middle School Social Studies Field I
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 4320 component of Phase II for MS students. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4320 course syllabi. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Middle School Social Studies Field Experience II
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4550 component of Phase II for MS students. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4550 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Middle School Science I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7340). Concepts, materials, methods in middle school program.

courses.name: Middle School Science I - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7340). Concepts, materials, methods in middle school program.

courses.name: Middle School Science Field I
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 4340 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4340 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Middle School Science II
courses.description: Concepts, materials, methods in the middle school program.

courses.name: Middle School Science Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4350 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4350 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Intro. Teaching Mathematics in Middle and Secondary Schools
courses.description: Introduction to teaching mathematics including: professional mathematics teacher associations and journals, learning theories related to teaching mathematics, tools, and materials for teaching mathematics, curriculum and instructional strategies (middle and lower high school level), and techniques for assessing mathematical understanding.

courses.name: Intro. Teaching Math in Middle and Secondary School Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4360 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4360 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching and Modeling Middle School Mathematics
courses.description: Major issues/topics of the course include: nature of middle school students, lesson planning, developing and utilizing teaching strategies, assessment alternatives, teaching via problem solving and mathematical modeling, interdisciplinary strategies and materials, and techniques for assessing mathematical understanding.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4360 or LTC 7360 and LTC 4581 or 7581
courses.recommendation: Admittance to Phase II and at least 18 credit hours of required mathematics

courses.name: Teaching and Modeling Middle School Mathematics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Major issues/topics of the course include: nature of middle school students, lesson planning, developing and utilizing teaching strategies, assessment alternatives, teaching via problem solving and mathematical modeling, interdisciplinary strategies and materials, and techniques for assessing mathematical understanding.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4360 or LTC 7360 and LTC 4581 or 7581
courses.recommendation: Admittance to Phase II and at least 18 credit hours of required mathematics

courses.name: Teaching and Modeling Middle School Mathematics Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4370 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4370 course syllabi.  Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Middle School Language Arts I
courses.description: Integrates an understanding of literacy (highlighting reading) with content area demands, literature and other media texts, evaluation and inquiry within a context of diversity.

courses.name: Teaching Middle School Language Arts I Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4380 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4380 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts II
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators with the knowledge, skills, and strategies necessary for integrating and teaching the English/Language Arts, primarily focusing on the teaching of writing and critical thinking.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts II - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators with the knowledge, skills, and strategies necessary for integrating and teaching the English/Language Arts, primarily focusing on the teaching of writing and critical thinking.

courses.name: Teaching Middle School Language Arts II Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4390 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4390 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts III
courses.description: Prepare prospective educators by focusing on the teaching of American culture and critical thinking, through literacy, mediacy, oracy, and cultural artifacts.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4380 or LTC 7380 and LTC 4390 or LTC 7390

courses.name: Teaching Middle School Language Arts III Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4400 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4400 course syllabi.  Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching, Engaging and Assessing Middle-Level Students
courses.description: In this course students will learn about the specific and individual needs of middle-level students and develop the skills and understandings to meet these needs.

courses.name: Teaching, Engaging and Assessing Middle-Level Students - Writing Intensive
courses.description: In this course students will learn about the specific and individual needs of middle-level students and develop the skills and understandings to meet these needs.

courses.name: Teaching, Engaging & Assessing Mid-Level Students Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4410 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4410 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Adolescent Literacy
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7420). Explores literacy implications of content areas. Topics include determining the difficulty of text, examining literature that supports content, creating alternative assessments, and evaluating reading/writing strategies as tools for learning. (Required of all students obtaining certification in middle school or concurrent certification in middle and secondary school area(s) except language arts.

courses.name: Middle School Literacy Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4420 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4420 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4650; cross-leveled with LTC 7460, LINGST 7650). Linguistic and pedagogical principles of teaching English to speakers of other languages. Graded A-F only.

courses.name: Teaching Secondary English/Language Arts I
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators with the knowledge, skills, and strategies necessary for integrating and teaching the English/Language Arts, Primarily focusing on Young Adult Literature and critical thinking.

courses.name: Teaching Secondary English/Language Arts I Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4470 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4470 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts II
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators with the knowledge and strategies necessary for integrating and teaching the English/Language Arts, primarily focusing on the teaching of writing and critical thinking.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts II - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators with the knowledge and strategies necessary for integrating and teaching the English/Language Arts, primarily focusing on the teaching of writing and critical thinking.

courses.name: Teaching Secondary English/Language Arts II Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4480 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4480 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts III
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators by focusing on the teaching of American culture and critical thinking, through literacy, mediacy, oracy, and cultural artifacts.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4470 or LTC 7470 and LTC 4480 or LTC 7480

courses.name: Teaching Secondary English/Language Arts III Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4490 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4490 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Emergent Language in Early Childhood
courses.description: Study of language learning in young children; how meaning of the environment is gained through language; implications for teachers working with children from varying language-learning environments.

courses.name: Assessment in Early Childhood Education
courses.description: A study of formal and informal assessment instruments and procedures used to measure progress and determine developmentally appropriate curriculum for children in early childhood settings.
courses.recommendation: H_D_FS 3420 or equivalent child development or child psychology course

courses.name: Literature in the Elementary School
courses.description: Surveys the field of literature for children and adolescents, with emphasis on selected readings of various types of literature.

courses.name: Introduction to Social Studies
courses.description: Will introduce prospective teachers to the profession of social studies teaching; to the bases for making curriculum choices in social studies and the process of choosing content; and the process of planning curriculum and instruction in social studies classrooms.

courses.name: Secondary Social Studies I Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 4530 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4530 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching of Reading
courses.description: Materials, methods used in teaching reading in elementary grades.

courses.name: Reading and Writing in the Social Studies
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7541). Focuses on the teaching of reading and writing strategies for social studies teachers. Students review literacy interventions related to reading and writing historical texts. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Secondary Social Studies II Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 4541 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4541 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Assessment in Social Studies
courses.description: Will address the purposes and development of social studies assessment for all levels from classroom to national assessment.  Assessment will be used to reflect upon curriculum/instruction, make revisions and set goals.

courses.name: Assessment in Social Studies - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Will address the purposes and development of social studies assessment for all levels from classroom to national assessment.  Assessment will be used to reflect upon curriculum/instruction, make revisions and set goals.

courses.name: Secondary Social Studies III Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4550 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4550 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Reading and Writing in the Content Areas
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7560). For secondary school teachers.  Specific ways teachers can help students improve reading and writing skills in content areas and ways they can be taught.

courses.name: Reading and Writing in the Content Areas II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7565). Reading and Writing in the Content Areas II explores specific reading and writing content area strategies, with a focus on struggling students and new investigations in disciplinary literacy.

courses.name: Organization of Public School Art
courses.description: Purposes, practices of art experiences in elementary and secondary schools. Designed for teachers, supervisors, administrators.

courses.name: Introduction to Teaching Mathematics in Middle and Secondary Schools
courses.description: Introduction to teaching mathematics including: professional mathematics teacher associations and journals, learning theories related to teaching mathematics, tools, and materials for teaching mathematics, curriculum and instructional strategies (middle and lower high school level), and techniques for assessing mathematical understanding. Recommended: Admittance to Phase II

courses.name: Intro. Teaching Math in Middle and Secondary School Field Experience
courses.description: Field experience supporting the LTC 4571 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4571 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Social Studies in the Elementary School
courses.description: Problems in preparation, teaching of units with suitable materials, techniques.

courses.name: Teaching Mathematics in Middle and Secondary Schools: Focus on Algebra and Technology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7581). Key issues in the teaching of pre-algebra through advanced algebra, appropriate use of technology, lesson planning, integration of appropriate models, mathematical connections.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4571 or LTC 7571 or LTC 4360 or LTC 7360

courses.name: Teaching Math in Middle and Secondary Schools: Algebra and Technology Field
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 4581/7581 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4581/LTC 7581 course syllabi.   Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Seminar in Curriculum and Instruction

courses.name: Teach.Math in Sec.Schools: Focus on Geometry, Probability and Statistics
courses.description: Provides experience which advanced students' knowledge, understanding, and facility in engaging students in learning mathematics. Major issues/topics highlighted in the course are: exploration of curriculum, teaching strategies, and assessment for geometry, probability and statistics.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4571 or LTC 7571 and LTC 4581 or LTC 7581

courses.name: Teach.Math in Sec.Schools: Focus on Geometry, Probability and Statistics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Provides experience which advanced students' knowledge, understanding, and facility in engaging students in learning mathematics. Major issues/topics highlighted in the course are: exploration of curriculum, teaching strategies, and assessment for geometry, probability and statistics.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4571 or LTC 7571 and LTC 4581 or LTC 7581

courses.name: Teach Math in Sec Sch: Focus on Geometry/Probability
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4590 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4590 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Diagnosis and Remediation of Learning Problems in Math - Middle
courses.description: The study of diagnostic and remedial instructional techniques for the teaching of mathematics. Emphasis is placed on alternative teaching methods and strategies.

courses.name: Teaching Techniques and Curriculum in Elementary School Math
courses.description: The mathematics program in the elementary school from viewpoint of goals, content, techniques and evaluation.

courses.name: Information Literacy in Teaching and Learning
courses.description: Discusses the nature, value, and power of information as product and process; organization, retrieval, and evaluation of information; explores the Internet and information superhighway; develops skills for resource based learning for classroom instruction; policy issues.

courses.name: Health Education in the Elementary School
courses.description: Defines teacher's role in school health program; investigates health needs of school children; focuses on teaching strategies, health resources and development of elementary school health education curricula and materials.

courses.name: Teach.Sci.Second.Sch.:Phil.,Hist., Sci.Inq.,Curr., Assm., & Teach I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7631). An integration of the philosophy and history of science, technology, society; teaching science as inquiry; classroom management, strategies and curricula for teaching/learning science; and using technology in science learning.

courses.name: Teach.Sci.Second.Sch.:Phil.,Hist., Sci.Inq.,Curr., Assm., & Teach I - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 7631). An integration of the philosophy and history of science, technology, society; teaching science as inquiry; classroom management, strategies and curricula for teaching/learning science; and using technology in science learning.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary Science I Field
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 4631 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4631 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Motor Development in Early Childhood
courses.description: Motor development of infants and children with emphasis on: study of interaction between biological and environmental factors affecting development, motor assessment techniques, and designing programs to enhance motor development.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary Science II
courses.description: An integration of the philosophy and history of science, technology, society; teaching science as inquiry; classroom management, strategies and curricula for teaching/learning science; and using technology in science learning.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary Science II Field
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4641 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4641 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Education in Human Sexuality
courses.description: The biological, psychosocial and educational aspects of human sexuality with special emphasis on instructional activities related to interpersonal communication, decision-making ability and clarification of values, course is designed for both teachers and health-care personnel.

courses.name: Teach.Sci.Second.Sch.:Phil.,Hist.,Sci.Inq.,Curr.,Assm., & Tech III
courses.description: An integration of the philosophy and history of science, technology, society; teaching science as inquiry; classroom management, strategies and curricula for teaching/learning science; and using technology in science learning.

courses.name: Teach Sci Second Sch: Phil,Hist,Sci Inq,Curr,Assm & Tech III Fld
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4651 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4651 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Drug Education
courses.description: The psychosocial, legal and pharmacological aspects of the recreational use of over-the-counter and street drugs are investigated with emphasis being placed on personal decision making, principles of school and community drug education, rehabilitation and community health services.

courses.name: Teaching Legal Rights and Responsibilities of Citizenship
courses.description: An introductory course for teachers and undergraduate students dealing with the teaching of the basic legal concepts which underlie effective citizenship.

courses.name: Overview of Art Education
courses.description: This is the first of a three course sequence and serves as the foundation for inquiries of methodological and philosophical approaches to the teaching of the visual arts at the elementary and secondary level.

courses.name: Overview of Art Education Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 4730 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4730 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Inquiry into Art Education
courses.description: The second of three course sequence. It will cover art education issues as they apply to the Pre-School through Middle School setting.

courses.name: Inquiry into Art Education
courses.description: The second of three course sequence. It will cover art education issues as they apply to the Pre-School through Middle School setting.

courses.name: Inquiry into Art Education: Pre-School Through Middle School Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4740 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4740 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Inquiry into Art Education
courses.description: The third of a three course sequence. Student will learn about secondary art education and make application to practice with emphasis on adolescent development, curriculum design, student assessment, instruction, diversity/equity, and professionalism.

courses.name: Inquiry into Art Education: Secondary Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 4750 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 4750 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Special Readings in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Directed study of literature and research reports in education.

courses.name: Standardized Assessments
courses.description: This non-credit course will provide resources to assist with standardized assessments required to become a Missouri certified teacher.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Internship and Capstone Seminar
courses.description: Internship is a full-semester experience in the public schools, including a capstone seminar addressing problems of practice (integrating subjects, reading and writing across the curriculum, meeting all students' needs), and evaluation of the interns preparation for entering the profession. It is offered each Fall and Spring for 10-16 credit hours. Admittance to College of Education required.

courses.name: Internship I
courses.description: This field experience provides preservice interns a semester-long public school experience where they simultaneously engage in a unique combination of observation and teaching. Through observation, conferencing, reading, discussion, demonstration, and participation, the preservice intern will synthesize the course concepts of the Senior Year On-Site Program (SYOSP). Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Student Teaching
courses.description: Hours, credit must be arranged with director of student teaching. Must apply during February for following year.
courses.prerequisites: special methods courses in area of specialization

courses.name: Inquiring into Schools, Community and Society I
courses.description: This course focuses on schooling in American society, the school community, the school culture and students' lives and identities. Studied are the political, cultural, and economic conditions of the schools.
courses.prerequisites: TDP 2020 and completion of Phase I or enrollment in a graduate level program in the College of Education

courses.name: Problems in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Studies professional programs and issues in health or physical education.

courses.name: Assessment and Family Collaboration in Early Childhood Education
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4091). Strategies for effectively observing and assessing young children and strategies for building positive family and community relationships, which support children's development and learning.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required (enrollment limited to students admitted to Phase II)

courses.name: Working with Infants and Toddlers
courses.description: Experience working with children aged 6 weeks to 2 1/2 years and their families. Opportunity to apply theories of cognitive, language, and social development.
courses.prerequisites: course in child development and admission to Phase II; admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Early Childhood Education Literacy Methods & Assessment I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4120). Strategies for assessing and supporting young children's literacy development.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: Admittance to College of Education required and co enrollment in LTC 4200 and LTC 4210 and K-3 field experience

courses.name: Emergent & Developing Literacy Early Childhood Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 7120 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7120 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching & Learning Math, Sci. & Social Studies w/Young Children
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4130). Strategies for assessing and supporting young children's math, science and social studies learning. Includes strategies for home-school collaboration. Must take concurrently with K-3 field experience.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required (enrollment is limited to students admitted to the College of Education and have completed of ECE Language/Literacy block)

courses.name: Teach & Learn Math, Sci & Soc Studies w/Young Children Fld Exp
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 7130 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7130 course syllabi. . Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Curriculum, Theory and  Classroom Management in Early Childhood Education
courses.description: Reflection on the relationship of theory and practice in ECE. Consideration of various topics including historical influences on early childhood curriculum, models of early childhood curriculum, classroom management, and individualizing curriculum.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required (enrollment limited to students who have completed the first two semesters of Phase II)

courses.name: Early Childhood Education Literacy Teaching Methods and Assessment II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4150). Advanced strategies for assessing and supporting young children's literacy development.
courses.recommendation: LTC 4120 or LTC 7120, LTC 4124 K-3 Field Experience and admittance to the ECE certification program in Phase II of the College of Education

courses.name: Motor Development in Young Children
courses.description: For Early Childhood majors.  Study of young children's motor development.  Must be taken as part of the TDP ECE Motor/Art/Music block.

courses.name: Young Children's Emergent Language
courses.description: For Early Childhood and Elementary Education majors. Study of young children's language development and implications for teachers.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to Phase II; admittance to College of Education requiredCorequisites: LTC 4120, LTC 4210, and K-3 field experience

courses.name: Children's Language and Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4210) For Early Childhood majors. Examines children's oral language development and surveys the field of children's literature for children ages birth to eight.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to Phase II; admittance to College of Education requiredCorequisites: LTC 7120 and K-3 field experience

courses.name: Emergent Literacy
courses.description: Emergent reading. Instructional methods, diagnostic procedures, and materials appropriate for learners in elementary grades 1-3.

courses.name: Emergent Literacy Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 7220 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7220 course syllabi. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Art for Children
courses.description: This course focuses on appropriate teaching methods and strategies for teaching art (studio, art history, aesthetic, and criticism), artistic development of children, and curriculum, instructional, and organization strategies for the art classroom.

courses.name: Middle School Science I
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4340). Concepts, materials, methods in middle school science.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required. (enrollment limited to Phase I admittance; admittance to the College of Education required)

courses.name: Middle School Science II
courses.description: Concepts, materials, methods in the middle school program.
courses.prerequisites: Phase I; admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Intro. Teaching Mathematics in Middle & Secondary
courses.description: Introduction to teaching mathematics including: professional mathematics teacher associations and journals, learning theories related to teaching mathematics, tools, and materials for teaching mathematics, curriculum and instructional strategies (middle and lower high school level), and techniques for assessing mathematical understanding.
courses.prerequisites: professional standing, MATH 1360; admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Teaching and Modeling Middle School Mathematics
courses.description: Major issues/topics of the course include: nature of middle school students, lesson planning, developing and utilizing teaching strategies, assessment alternatives, teaching via problem solving and mathematical modeling, interdisciplinary strategies and materials, and techniques for assessing mathematical understanding.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4360 or LTC 7360 and at least 18 hours of required mathematics; admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Teaching Middle School Language Arts I
courses.description: Integrates an understanding of literacy (highlighting reading) with content area demands, literature and other media texts, evaluation and inquiry within a context of diversity.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to Phase II of College of Education

courses.name: Middle School Language Arts I Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 7380 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7380 course syllabi. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts II
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators with the knowledge, skills, and strategies necessary for integrating and teaching the English/Language Arts, primarily focusing on the teaching of writing and critical thinking.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to Phase II of College of Education

courses.name: Middle School Language Arts II Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 7390 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7390 course syllabi. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts III
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators by focusing on the teaching of American culture and critical thinking, through literacy, mediacy, oracy, and cultural artifacts.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4380 or LTC 7380 and LTC 4390 or LTC 7390; admittance to Phase II of College of Education

courses.name: Middle School Language Arts III Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 7400 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7400 course syllabi. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching, Engaging and Assessing Middle-Level Students
courses.description: In this course students will learn about the specific and individual needs of middle-level students and develop the skills and understandings to meet these needs.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Teaching, Engaging & Assessing Mid-Level Students
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 7410 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7410 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Adolescent Literacy
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4420). Explores literacy implications of content areas. Topics include determining the difficulty of text, examining literature that supports content, creating alternative assessments, and evaluating reading/writing strategies as tools for learning. (Required of all students obtaining certification in middle school or concurrent certification in middle and secondary school area(s) except language arts.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Middle School Literacy Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 7420 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7420 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 7650). Linguistics and pedagogical principles of teaching English to speakers of other languages. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 7600 and ENGLSH 7610 or equivalent and acceptance into Phase II

courses.name: Teaching Secondary English/Language Arts I
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators with the knowledge, skills, and strategies necessary for integrating and teaching the English/ Language Arts, primarily focusing on Young Adult Literature and critical thinking.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to Phase II of College of Education

courses.name: Teaching English/Language Arts I Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 7470 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7470 course syllabi. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts II
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators with the knowledge, skills, and strategies necessary for integrating and teaching the English/ language Arts, primarily focusing on the teaching of writing and critical thinking.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to Phase II of College of Education

courses.name: Teaching English/Language Arts II Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the Learning, Teaching and Curriculum 7480 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7480 course syllabi. Graded on an S/U basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary English/Language Arts III
courses.description: Prepares prospective educators by focusing on the teaching of American culture and critical thinking, through literacy, mediacy, oracy, and cultural artifacts.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4470 or LTC 7470 and LTC 4480 or LTC 7480; admittance to Phase II of College of Education

courses.name: Language Arts III Field Experience
courses.description: This field experience supports the LTC 7490 component of Phase II. Field experience expectations are delineated in the LTC 7490 course syllabi. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Emergent Language in Early Childhood
courses.description: Study of language learning in young children; how meaning of the environment is gained through language; implications for teachers working with children from varying language-learning environments.

courses.name: Assessment in Early Childhood Education
courses.description: A study of formal and informal assessment instruments and procedures used to measure progress and determine developmentally appropriate curriculum for children in early childhood settings.

courses.name: Literature in the Elementary School
courses.description: Surveys the field of literature for children and adolescents, with emphasis on selected readings of various types of literature.

courses.name: Teaching of Reading
courses.description: Materials, methods used in teaching reading in elementary grades.

courses.name: Teaching Social Studies
courses.description: Is designed for the secondary social studies teachers to develop knowledge of social studies and the skills to teach social studies. The student will plan implement, and evaluate both the teaching and learning processes for secondary social studies classroom.
courses.prerequisites: acceptance into Phase II,  admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Assessment in Social Studies
courses.description: Will address the purposes and development of social studies assessment for all levels from classroom to national assessment. Assessment will be used to reflect upon curriculum/instruction, make revisions and set goals.
courses.prerequisites: acceptance into Phase II, admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Reading and Writing in Content Areas
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4560). For secondary school teachers.  Specific ways teachers can help students improve reading and writing skills in content areas and ways they can be taught.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required (enrollment is limited to College of Education admitted to Phase II with 60+ credit hours)

courses.name: Reading and Writing in the Content Areas II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4565). Reading and Writing in the Content Areas II explores specific reading and writing content area strategies, with a focus on struggling students and new investigations in disciplinary literacy.

courses.name: Organization of Public School Art
courses.description: Purposes, practices of art experiences in elementary and secondary schools. Designed for teachers, supervisors, administrators.

courses.name: Introduction Teaching Mathematics in Middle and Secondary
courses.description: Introduction to teaching mathematics including: professional mathematics teacher associations and journals, learning theories related to teaching mathematics, tools, and materials for teaching mathematics, curriculum and instructional strategies (middle and lower high school level), and techniques for assessing mathematical understanding.

courses.name: Social Studies in the Elementary School
courses.description: Problems in preparation, teaching of units with suitable materials, techniques.

courses.name: Teaching Mathematics in Middle and Secondary Schools: Focus on Algebra and Technology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4581). Key issues in the teaching of pre-algebra through advanced algebra, appropriate uses of technology, lesson planning, integration of appropriate models, mathematical connections.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Seminar in Curriculum and Instruction.

courses.name: Teach.Math in Sec.Schools: Focus on Geometry, Probability & Stat.
courses.description: Provides experience which advanced students' knowledge, understanding, and facility in engaging students in learning mathematics. Major issues/topics highlighted in the course are: exploration of curriculum, teaching strategies, and assessment for geometry, probability and statistics.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 4570 or LTC 7570; admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Diagnosis and  Remediation of Learning Problems in Math-Middle
courses.description: The study of diagnostic and remedial instructional techniques for the teaching of mathematics. Emphasis is placed on alternative teaching methods and strategies.

courses.name: Teaching Techniques and Curriculum in Elementary School Math
courses.description: The mathematics program in the elementary school from viewpoint of goals, content, techniques and evaluation.

courses.name: Information Literacy in Teaching and Learning
courses.description: Discusses the nature, value, and power of information as product and process; organization, retrieval, and evaluation of information; explores the Internet and information superhighway; develops skills for resource based learning for classroom instruction; policy issues.

courses.name: Health Education in the Elementary School
courses.description: Defines teacher's role in school health program; investigates health needs of school children; focuses on teaching strategies, health resources and development of elementary school health education curricula and materials.

courses.name: Teach.Sci.Second.Sch.:Phil.,Hist., Sci.Inq.,Curr.,Assm., & Tech 3
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LTC 4631). An integration of the philosophy and history of science, technology, society; teaching science as inquiry; classroom management, strategies and curricula for teaching/learning science; and using technology in science learning.
courses.prerequisites: Consent required (professional standing; admittance to College of Education required)

courses.name: Motor Development in Early Childhood
courses.description: Motor development of infants and children with emphasis on: study of interaction between biological and environmental factors affecting development, motor assessment techniques, and designing programs to enhance motor development.

courses.name: Teaching Middle and Secondary Science II
courses.description: An integration of the philosophy and history of science, technology, society; teaching science as inquiry; classroom management, strategies and curricula for teaching/learning science; and using technology in science learning.
courses.prerequisites: professional standing and Teaching Science in the Secondary School, Part I; admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Education in Human Sexuality
courses.description: The biological, psychosocial and educational aspects of human sexuality with special emphasis on instructional activities related to interpersonal communication, decision-making ability and clarification of values, course is designed for both teachers and health-care personnel.

courses.name: Teach.Sci.Second.Sch.:Phil.,Hist.,Sci.Inq.,Curr.,Assm., & Tech 2
courses.description: An integration of the philosophy and history of science, technology, society; teaching science as inquiry; classroom management, strategies and curricula for teaching/learning science; and using technology in science learning.
courses.prerequisites: professional standing and Teaching Science in the Secondary School, Parts 1 and II; admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Drug Education
courses.description: The psychosocial, legal and pharmacological aspects of the recreational use of over-the-counter and street drugs are investigated with emphasis being placed on personal decision making, principles of school and community drug education, rehabilitation and community health services.

courses.name: Teaching Legal Rights and Responsibilities of Citizenship
courses.description: An introductory course for teachers and undergraduate students dealing with the teaching of the basic legal concepts which underlie effective citizenship.

courses.name: Overview of Art Education
courses.description: This is the first of a three course sequence and serves as the foundation for inquiries of methodological and philosophical approaches to the teaching of the visual arts at the elementary and secondary level.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Inquiry into Art Education
courses.description: The second of three course sequence. It will cover art education issues as they apply to the Pre-School through Middle School setting.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Inquiry into Art Education
courses.description: The third of a three course sequence. Student will learn about secondary art education and make application to practice with emphasis on adolescent development, curriculum design, student assessment, instruction, diversity/equity, and professionalism.
courses.prerequisites: admittance to College of Education required

courses.name: Special Readings in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Directed study of literature and research reports in education.

courses.name: Internship and Capstone Seminar
courses.description: Internship is a full-semester experience in the public schools, including a capstone seminar addressing problems of practice (integrating subjects, reading and writing across the curriculum, meeting all students' needs), and evaluation of the interns preparation for entering the profession. It is offered each Fall and Spring for 1-16 credit hours. Admittance to College of Education required.
courses.prerequisites: ED_LPA 4060 or ED_LPA 7060 and admittance into Phase III

courses.name: Problems in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Problems in Curriculum and Instruction.

courses.name: Tests and Measurements for Elementary and Secondary Schools
courses.description: Educational tests, measurements from points of view of teachers, supervisors, administrators.

courses.name: Home-School Partnerships: Working with Families
courses.description: Examination of theoretical and philosophical foundations of parent involvement, social and cultural influences on contemporary families, current research on parent involvement, and characteristics of effective home-school-community partnerships.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Issues in Early Childhood Education and Curriculum Practices
courses.description: Focuses on historical and contemporary societal and educational issues affecting current curriculum decisions and practices in kindergarten and primary grades.
courses.prerequisites: Classroom teaching experience or instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Early Childhood Curriculum
courses.description: Study of early childhood curriculum in contemporary educational settings along with selection of appropriate materials and development of instructional strategies for children, prekindergarten through early primary grades.

courses.name: Advanced Assessment in Early Childhood
courses.description: (same as SPC_ED 8490).  Procedures and instruments used in assessment of young children, including screening, diagnosis, interpretation of diagnostic findings, and application to instructional plans. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: May be restricted to students in semester-based courses offered through Mizzou Online

courses.name: Language and Early Literacy Development
courses.description: Investigation of the language and early literacy development of young children from birth through age 8. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: May be restricted to students in semester-based courses offered through Mizzou Online

courses.name: The Missouri Writing Project
courses.description: Focus on 1) current theory and research in teaching writing; 2) development of effective practice in teaching, writing and reading; and 3) experimentation with writing and response.

courses.name: The Teaching of Journalism
courses.description: The course focuses on the learning and teaching of middle, secondary, and post-secondary journalism/mass media course. Major strands of study include the theory and practice of journalism instruction, curriculum, and assessment.

courses.name: Teaching Writing in Middle and Secondary Classroom
courses.description: This course will encourage the student as a writer and as a teacher of writing, especially in the middle and high school setting.  We will explore various types of writing, with emphasis in English Education, including addressing national and state standards.

courses.name: Writing, Reading and Teaching Nonfiction
courses.description: Students will get more than their feet wet as they read and write a variety of nonfiction texts, explore nonfiction's value and relationship to other genres, and investigate its potential for learning.

courses.name: Media Literacy
courses.description: Teachers will learn how to incorporate visual images in the classroom while helping students "read" the images of our media-rich culture.  Teachers will pair media with literature; analyzed and evaluate different media; and design several assignments.

courses.name: Whole Language Curriculum
courses.description: Whole Language Curriculum inquires into whole language theory, beliefs and practices. Students will explore and participate in classroom based inquiry projects, theme cycles, reflective practices, holistic assessment, and other learner-centered experiences such as literature study and writers workshop.

courses.name: Talk in the Curriculum
courses.description: This survey of oracy examines talk's essential role in learning and the connections among language, power and cultural identity.

courses.name: Language Acquisition and Development
courses.description: You will explore theories of language acquisition and development, and examine how language acquisition impacts reading and writing. Ideas for creating a language rich curriculum, second language learning, and cultural aspects of language will be addressed.

courses.name: Teaching Reading Through Literature Response
courses.description: Teaching Reading Through Literature Response focuses on 1) reading as a personal and social process and 2) multiple responses to literature. Students will examine, use and critique; personalized reading, text sets (conceptually related materials), literature groups and other reading instruction experiences.

courses.name: Literature for Children and Youth
courses.description: Systematic study of selected areas of particular importance to students of literature, teachers, librarians, supervisors, and school administrators.

courses.name: Teaching Literature
courses.description: This course involves exploration of theory, research, and practice in the teaching and learning of literature to students in Grades 9-12. It is intended for master's and doctoral students - experienced teachers enrolled in MU's English Education graduate program. This course addresses selected Common Core Standards, and focuses on an integrated approach to the teaching of literature and some nonfiction. Texts include novels, short stories, poems, literary nonfiction, and plays. The teaching of critical thinking, research skills, and technology are integrated into these experiences. This course promotes the use of various teaching and learning practices. The course is divided into the following major sections: 1) Introductions of Class Members; 2) Theories of Teaching Literature in the Classroom; and 3) Trying Out Theories on Selected Literature. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: This is a recommended course for early in a master's program

courses.name: Teaching Communication
courses.description: This course explores the theory, research, and practice in the teaching and learning of communication.   This course is intended for master's and doctoral students - experienced teachers enrolled in MU's English Education graduate program. This course addresses selected Common Core Standards, and focuses on the teaching of speaking, listening, and language, as they occur within the  best practices of English/Language Arts classrooms. The course involves variety of texts such as short stories, poems, literary nonfiction, and plays. The teaching of critical thinking, research skills, and technology are integrated into these experiences. This course encourages the use of various teaching and learning practices. The course is divided into the following major themes: 1) Introductions of Class Members; 2) Overview of Communication: Theory, Research, Practice; and 3) Teaching Communication in Context: Speaking, Listening, Reading, Writing.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: We recommended, but do not require, that you take this course early in your program

courses.name: Studies in English Education
courses.description: Exploration of the theory, research, and application of topics in the teaching of English, such as Writing/Thinking, Media, Literature, Language, and Creative Nonfiction. Topics announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Foundations of English Education
courses.description: This course focuses on foundational readings in the teaching and learning of English/Language Arts. The course requires intensive reading, writing, and discussion focusing on four subcategories of English Education: writing, literature, language and critical thinking. In addition, the course situates these topics within a historical perspective of the field. An additional focus of this course is on professional networking and development. It is expected that as students develop a greater understanding of the foundations of English Studies in Language Arts, they will see where their areas of expertise and knowledge join them to the profession as a leader. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Writing and Reading in Content Areas
courses.description: Theory and practice of teaching reading and writing.  Specific ways teachers can help students use writing to communicate about the course content, as well as to learn course concepts.  Class also focuses on how to teach reading in reading classes, how to help students improve reading skills in content areas, and how reading and writing skills can reinforce each other.

courses.name: Teaching ESL/EFL to Adult Learners
courses.description: This course explores the characteristics of adult learners, theories of adult learning, and the contexts in which adults learn English as a second or foreign language. Students apply this knowledge in the design of language learning curricula and activities for adult learners. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching English Grammar and Pronunciation
courses.description: This course develops teachers' knowledge of the structure of the English language (its grammar and its sound system) and provides them with pedagogical skills in teaching grammar and pronunciation to second/foreign language learners. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Second Language Acquisition
courses.description: This course examines theories of how humans develop first and second languages in childhood and adulthood and how this knowledge can be used to educate language learners.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Materials for and Assessment of English Language Learners
courses.description: This course will examine the appropriate classroom materials, methods, reasons, and tools for the formal and informal assessment of English Language Learners.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Language and Culture for Educators
courses.description: This course will examine how to prepare educators to effectively educate students from a range of linguistic and cultural backgrounds by developing a broad understanding of the definition and nature of culture and appropriate teaching strategies and materials for diverse students.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Linguistics for Educators
courses.description: This course focuses on the form, meaning, and use of language in context and applying knowledge of linguistics to the teaching of English language learners.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Methods of Teaching English Language Learners
courses.description: This course will examine how to prepare teachers to develop the investigative, decision-making, and reflective teaching skills needed to work with English Language Learners.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: English to Speakers of Other Languages Practicum
courses.description: This culminating course will allow students to apply the theory and practice of teaching English to non-native speakers in an educational setting.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Working with English Language Learners with Special Needs
courses.description: The course will assist educators with the decision to refer or not to refer an English language learner to special education services while helping identify the general framework for considering their special needs and preparing a comprehensive continuum of services. Course graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Seminar: English: Its Grammar and Place in the World
courses.description: The course will familiarize learners with the grammatical features of English that have contributed to the its global proliferation, explore the varieties of English used around the world, and delve into the concept of English as a global means of communication. Course graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Education Toward Bi/Multilingualism: Theory, Policy, and Practice
courses.description: (same as ED_LPA 8653). Overview of the theory, policy, and practice of using at least two languages in education to develop children's bi/multilingualism. Key topics include: (1) models of bilingual/multilingual education; (2) policy and politics of language education in the U.S. and international contexts; (3) psycholinguistic and sociocultural perspectives on bi/multilingual language development, as related to schooling; and (4) evaluation and assessment issues in bi/multilingual education.

courses.name: Reading Miscue Analysis
courses.description: The process in which readers construct meaning by relating their socio-psycholinguistic backgrounds to discourse. 15 studied miscues (text deviations) are analyzed at several linguistic levels. A comprehension centered reading program is developed.

courses.name: Practicum in Child Study I
courses.description: Practicum experiences in diagnosing educational problems of school children.

courses.name: Practicum in Child Study II
courses.description: Practicum experiences in applying remedial procedures to children with educational problems.

courses.name: Analysis & Correction of Reading Disabilities
courses.description: Diagnostic and corrective procedures in reading instruction that may be used for clinical study.

courses.name: Foundations of Reading Instruction
courses.description: This online course examines principles and practices of teaching reading to PK-12 students; the nature of reading and literacy learning, the foundations of reading acquisition and development; and reading instructional across grade levels. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Issues and Trends in Reading Instruction
courses.description: Provides intensive study of significant issues and current trends in reading on all instructional levels.
courses.prerequisites: LTC 7540, LTC 7560 or equivalents or instructor's consent

courses.name: Making a Difference for the Struggling Reader
courses.description: Will help explore ways to help readers who have been unable to achieve success in reading--will learn how to access and evaluate strategies students are currently using.

courses.name: Focus on Writing in the Classroom
courses.description: The course focuses on theory, research and practices in teaching writing in the elementary classroom (K-6) while developing a critical understanding of process methods to teach writing.

courses.name: Celebrating Reading Through Good Books
courses.description: Many people can read but do not. This course will explore ways to make reading a joyful, exciting experience. Assignments will include reading journal articles that will help students meet self determined goals. Sharing books will be an important part of this course.

courses.name: Integrating Literacy and Technology
courses.description: This will be a seminar course in which the students explore definitions of literacy, theoretical frameworks of educational technology, and literature that investigates the effectiveness of integrating literacy and technology.  The students will also examine and evaluate a range of software used to integrate literacy and technology.

courses.name: Literature Opportunities: Using Children's and Young Adult's Literature in the Classroom
courses.description: This class examines genres in children's and young adult literature (grades 1-9). In-depth look at the work of children's authors and illustrators; explore issues of censorship, gender, and culture.

courses.name: Theory of Instructional Strategies
courses.description: The course investigates instructional strategies in K-12 and higher education classrooms and the theories behind those strategies. Content includes large and small group strategies, inquiry-based learning, student-centered and direct instruction, and differentiated instruction.

courses.name: Literacy and the Internet (Grades K-12)
courses.description: The internet offers a myriad of opportunities to engage K-12 students in meaningful, purpose-driven reading and writing. Students examine their own literacy programs, examine ways they can incorporate the internet, and create a classroom web site.

courses.name: Nature of Literacy in a Digital World
courses.description: New literacies are required to successfully engage in professional, civic, and personal lives that are imbued with technology.  Students examine the literacy skills required to proficiently read and write with text messages, blogs, wikis, social networks, and virtual worlds.

courses.name: Nature of Science and Science Teaching
courses.description: Examines philosophical, historical and sociological views of the nature of science and implications for science education policy and science instruction.

courses.name: Inquiry and the Science Curriculum
courses.description: Examines inquiry as the foundation of the science curriculum. Includes study of exemplary programs and curriculum materials, and provides models for curriculum development in science education.

courses.name: Research in Science Education
courses.description: Studies appropriate research methodologies and reviews research and selected readings in science education. Allows option for elementary or secondary emphasis for specific areas: life, physical or earth sciences.

courses.name: Trends and Issues in Science Education
courses.description: Provides intensive study of current trends and significant issues of science affecting both the elementary and secondary levels of science education.

courses.name: Teaching, Learning, & Research in Middle & Secondary School Sci.I
courses.description: Course I is for Post-Baccalaureate Majors seeking Middle and/or Secondary teacher certification. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching, Learning & Research Middle & Secondary School Sci.: II
courses.description: For Post-Baccalaureate Majors seeking Middle and/or Secondary teacher certification. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching, Learning, & Research Middle & Secondary
courses.description: For Post-Baccalaureate Majors seeking Middle and/or Secondary teacher certification. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Teaching of Elementary Science
courses.description: A study of science curriculum and teaching in elementary school from viewpoint of research teaching strategies, evaluation, and developing trends.
courses.prerequisites: teaching experience and science methods course

courses.name: Advanced Teaching of Secondary Science
courses.description: Studies secondary science curriculum and teaching from viewpoint of research strategies, teaching strategies, conceptional formats.

courses.name: College Science Teaching
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8724, PHYSCS 8310 and ASTRON 8310). Study of learner characteristics, teaching strategies, and research findings related to teaching science at the post-secondary level.
