courses.name: Science Outreach: Public Understanding of Science
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8725 and AN_SCI 8725). Development of presentations to adult audiences on the science underlying issues of current interest.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Integrating Science with Outreach
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8726). This course provides an opportunity for students to earn credit for outreach activities in the community.  Students will capitalize on their area of study and scientific expertise in developing, implementing, and evaluating related outreach activities.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Survey of Art Education
courses.description: Provides survey of the development of art education and problems in the field by means of a critical inquiry.

courses.name: Visual Literacy and Visual Culture
courses.description: This course will investigate the intersection between art and language, exploring the connections between visual media and the written word-how these two areas inform and enrich each other.

courses.name: Curriculum in Art Education
courses.description: Advanced study of art education curricula, with option for elementary or secondary emphasis. Study of exemplary art programs, standards of quality, curriculum models, curriculum design and construction, concomitant instructional methods and evaluation.

courses.name: Visual Thinking Strategies I
courses.description: This course will introduce regular classroom and art educators to Visual Thinking Strategies theory and methodology, building practical VTS facilitation skills through structured guidance and feedback as each participant implements VTS lessons within his/her own teaching context.

courses.name: Visual Thinking Strategies II
courses.description: Visual Thinking Strategies II students will build upon the basic facilitation skills acquired during VTS I as they design an image-based studio curriculum tailored to their own students and classrooms. Action research and peer coaching are key features of the course. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Review of Research in Art Education
courses.description: Studies appropriate research methodologies and reviews research and selected readings in art education.

courses.name: The Secondary School Curriculum
courses.description: For secondary school principals, teachers, superintendents. Presents trends in curricular change, methods of curricular investigation.

courses.name: Artistic Thinking: Multimedia Applications for Teaching Art
courses.description: This course is designed to keep pace with contemporary trends in technology and digital media literacies. Students will deeply explore current applications and develop curriculum implementation strategies for K-12 instruction in visual arts classrooms.

courses.name: Illuminating Process and Product: Making Learning Visible
courses.description: This course focuses on the evaluative processes that surround and are embedded in art education. Due to the subtle, nuanced, and product based nature of visual arts, evaluative practices should be studied, understood, and implemented in an effective and encouraging manner. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: The Art of Teacher Reflection
courses.description: This course investigates reflective practices making deep inquiries into theoretical teaching practices. Students will examine their educational heritage, cultural beliefs and the implications these beliefs have on their current and future classrooms. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Curriculum Construction for Secondary Schools
courses.description: Designed for those engaged in curriculum revision work and construction of new secondary school courses.

courses.name: Managing Classrooms for Learning
courses.description: Theoretical assumptions, goals, and research that inform various approaches to classroom management advocated for practitioners. Includes strategies for conducting action research on classroom management.
courses.prerequisites: An educational psychology course or instructor's consent

courses.name: Patterns for Instruction in Social Studies
courses.description: Presents and evaluates strategies for planning, teaching, and evaluating social studies in elementary and secondary schools.

courses.name: Secondary Social Studies Curriculum
courses.description: Examines current theory, trends and practices in secondary social studies curriculum with a practicum in curriculum development.

courses.name: Inquiry into K-12 History and Social Science
courses.description: this course is designed as a directed study on a topic in social studies content for the K-12 classroom.  The focus of the course is on what is taught in social studies.  Graded on A-F basis only

courses.name: Issues in the Social Studies Classroom
courses.description: This course is designed to provide an intensive study of current trends and significant issues in social studies that affect the social studies classroom.

courses.name: Elementary Social Studies Curriculum
courses.description: An in-depth study of objectives, goals, patterns and practices in elementary social studies curriculum. Focus will be upon instructional strategies and materials and current trends influencing curriculum development.

courses.name: Mathematics Curriculum
courses.description: Evolution of the mathematics curriculum during the 20th century will be studied. Emphasis will be given to examining major factors influencing the changing mathematics curriculum and their impact.
courses.prerequisites: teaching experience or the instructor's consent

courses.name: Teaching, Learning & Research in Middle & Secondary School Math I
courses.description: Course I for Post-Baccalaureate Majors seeking Middle and/or Secondary teacher certification. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching, Learning & Research Middle & Secondary School Math: II
courses.description: Course II for Post-Baccalaureate Majors seeking Middle and/or Secondary teacher certification. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching, Learning, and Research Middle and Secondary Math III
courses.description: Course III for Post-Baccalaureate Majors seeking Middle and/or Secondary teacher certification. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Assessment in Mathematics Education
courses.description: Examination of assessment practices and the accountability movement. Emphasis is placed on significant research findings in assessment and implications for planning, implementing, and evaluating mathematics instruction.

courses.name: Contemporary Curriculum Issues in Mathematics Education
courses.description: Mathematics curriculum is a concern to students, parents, school districts, business leaders, and government officials. This course examines current trends in mathematics curriculum from the perspective of mathematics educators, policymakers, and the public. Factors influencing changes in mathematics curriculum are examined. Graded on an A-F basis only.

courses.name: Mathematics Teaching and Teacher Education
courses.description: Recent developments and research findings in mathematics teaching and mathematics teacher education will be studied.
courses.prerequisites: Open to masters and doctoral students

courses.name: Teaching and Learning Number/Operations Advanced
courses.description: Course will develop understanding of learning and teaching pre-number concepts, counting and cardinality, numbers and operations in base ten. Emphasis will be given to how children think about and learn these concepts and how they fit into the elementary school curriculum. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching and Learning Rational Number Advanced
courses.description: The course is designed to develop an understanding of the learning and teaching of rational numbers and the ratio and proportional relationships. Emphasis will be given to how children think about and learn these concepts and how they fit into the elementary school curriculum. Graded on A-F basis only. Corequisites: LTC 8882

courses.name: Teaching and Learning Geometry and Measurement Advanced
courses.description: This course is designed to develop and understanding of the teaching and learning of geometry and measurement. Emphasis will be given to how children think about and learn these concepts and how they fit into an elementary mathematics curriculum. Graded on an A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching and Learning Algebraic Reasoning Advanced
courses.description: Course focuses on the content and complexities of teaching and assessing algebraic reasoning in grades 1-6. Includes examinations of representation, analysis of mathematical structures, patterns, functions, and the transition from arithmetic to algebra. Graded on A-F basis only. Corequisites: LTC 8884

courses.name: Technology and Mathematics Education
courses.description: This course will focus on effective uses of technology in mathematics teaching and learning.  Participants will experience different electronic technologies including computers, graphing calculators, and calculator based laboratories.
courses.prerequisites: Open to masters and doctoral students

courses.name: Teaching Data Analysis and Mathematical Modeling
courses.description: The course will develop understanding of data analysis and mathematical modeling. Emphasis will be given to how children think and learn about these concepts and how they fit into the elementary school curriculum. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Foundations of Mathematics Leadership in Elem Schools
courses.description: This course provides opportunities for participants to develop knowledge and understanding of leadership principles and the process of continuous improvement as it related to the roles and responsibilities of elementary mathematics specialists. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Mathematical Leadership for Elementary Schools Advanced
courses.description: This advanced leadership course focuses on research and practice related to teamwork, interaction, communication, conflict resolution, and leadership in K-5 schools. Candidates will examine effective strategies for influencing and facilitating school/district improvement. Course graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Survey of Theories of Learning Mathematics
courses.description: This course is designed for students to explore historical and current cognitive theories that frame research in teaching and learning of mathematics.

courses.name: Internship - Number and Operations in Elementary Schools
courses.description: A supervised mathematics teaching practicum with online seminars in which the candidate acquires experience working with a range of students and adult learners (parents and teachers) on number and operations concepts. Graded on A-F basis only. Corequisites: LTC 8871

courses.name: Internship - Rational Numbers in Elementary Schools
courses.description: A supervised mathematics teaching practicum with online seminars in which the candidate acquires experience working with a range of students and adult learners (teachers and parents) on rational number and proportional thinking concepts. Graded A-F basis only. Corequisites: LTC 8872

courses.name: Internship - Geometry/Measurement in Elementary Schools
courses.description: A supervised mathematics teaching practicum with online seminars in which the candidate acquires experience working with students and adult learners (teachers and parents) on geometry and measurement concepts appropriate for K-5 students. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Internship - Algebraic Reasoning in Elementary Schools
courses.description: A supervised mathematics teaching practicum with online seminars in which the candidate acquires experience working with a range of students and adult learners (teachers and parents) on concepts related to algebraic reasoning appropriate for K-5 students. Course graded on A-F basis only. Corequisites: LTC 8874

courses.name: Using Manipulative Materials in Teaching Mathematics III
courses.description: Mathematics laboratory is developed and integrated with experiences in setting. Emphasis on materials for primary and intermediate grades.

courses.name: Contemporary Equity Issues in Mathematics Education
courses.description: Certain student populations (e.g., socioeconomically disadvantaged, racial minorities, English Language Learners, students with disabilities) have been traditionally underserved by the U.S. mathematics education system. This course explores the fundamental issues underlying this situation and explores mathematics teaching techniques that can be used to make students' learning opportunities more equitable. Graded on an A-F basis only.

courses.name: Mathematics Education Research
courses.description: Examination of major research efforts and significant findings on learning and teaching mathematics. Emphasis will be placed on becoming knowledgeable of research and on developing wise consumers of research in mathematics education.

courses.name: Integrating Instruction in Science and Mathematics, Grades 5-12
courses.description: This course is designed to help middle and secondary mathematics and science teachers enhance student understanding of mathematics and science through integration of the disciplines.

courses.name: Advanced Methods of Teaching Secondary School Mathematics
courses.description: Discussion and application of theories of learning, strategies of instruction, curriculum development, evaluation techniques and research to secondary mathematics programs.
courses.prerequisites: Mathematics Secondary School Teaching Experience or equivalent

courses.name: Secondary Mathematics from an Advanced Perspective
courses.description: This course deepens understanding of the mathematics underlying the secondary school curriculum. It addresses high school content from the viewpoint of advanced mathematics. Connections are explored within high school content and between high school and college content. Content strands include analysis, algebra, and Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometry. Graded on an A-F basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Seminar in Curriculum and Instruction

courses.name: Individual Research
courses.description: Independent research not leading to thesis.

courses.name: Classroom Research-Learning, Teaching and Curriculum
courses.description: Study of original classroom research and theories of instruction leading to plans for personal research and theory development.

courses.name: Classroom Research-Early Childhood and Elementary
courses.description: Study of original classroom research and theories of instruction leading to plans for personal research and theory development.

courses.name: Ethnographic Research in Education
courses.description: Investigate practical aspects, nature, and assumptions of ethnographic research in education. Pilot study required.

courses.name: In-Service Course in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Course work adapted to current vocational needs.

courses.name: Internship in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Provides internship experience under supervision in advanced levels of curriculum and instruction.

courses.name: Advanced Internship in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: This internship is for students enrolled in MU COE Post-Baccalaureate Certification Programs. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Case Study Research Methods
courses.description: This course introduces graduate students to the advanced qualitative techniques related to case study research, within and across case coding strategies, and theoretical/philosophical underpinnings of case study research methodology.
courses.prerequisites: Previous introductory course in qualitative research methods is required

courses.name: Grounded Theory and Situated Inquiry
courses.description: For qualitative researchers attempting to understand social processes, Grounded Theory (GT) offers a way of developing theory empirically, 'from the bottom up.' In fact, this is what most distinguishes GT from other methods. It is explicitly emergent. It does not test a hypothesis. It provides useful tools to learn about participants' understandings and experiences of a social issue, process, or phenomena and to discover and construct theory to account for the social processes being studied. In this course, we will consider the theoretical underpinnings and practices of classic and contemporary GT methodologies. Importantly, we will conduct research and a GT analysis of data.

courses.name: Narrative Inquiry Theory and Research Methods
courses.description: Narrative inquiry has gained popularity amongst researchers specifically in education and other social science fields with various theoretical and analytical approaches. In this advanced qualitative course, students will learn about these approaches and develop critical perspectives toward narrative inquiry. The purpose of this course is to expose students, in various disciplines, to the theoretical underpinnings of narrative inquiry and provide space to "have a try" at several analytical methods for narrative research (i.e. thematic, structural, dialogic/performative, and image analysis). This course will equip students with narrative research method experiences that could be used for dissertation research.

courses.name: Poststructural Theory and Research Methods
courses.description: Poststructural perspectives call into question the universals and/or structures of society. The purpose of this course is to expose students, in various disciplines, to poststructural theory and provide space to "have a try" at thinking with theory for data analysis. This course provides space for students to read poststructural scholars' original writings. Readings for the course also allow students to read secondary sources and research studies that apply poststructural ideas. Students are encouraged to think of ways that poststructural theory can become a methodology and/or method for research in their discipline.

courses.name: Multimodal Analysis
courses.description: Multimodal analysis examines how multiple modes such as language, images, sound, symbols, gestures, body posture/position, space, and architecture are deployed for communication purposes in social science research.  Students will learn about multimodal theoretical frameworks, key concepts, and procedures in order to critically engage with semiotic resources in a variety of research contexts.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Discourse Analysis in Education
courses.description: (same as ED_LPA 8955).  This course introduces the theories and methods of discourse analysis, including conversation, critical discourse, and multimodal.  Students will analyze the role of context and ethics, as they transcribe and analyze discourse, especially from educational settings.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Collaborative Inquiry Through Photovoice
courses.description: Photovoice is a participatory action research method that invites participants to explore and document their lived experiences in order to spark dialogue with others to bring about change.  In this course, students experience the process of Photovoice in order to learn how to use this process in future research.

courses.name: Qualitative Methods in Educational Research I
courses.description: (same as ESC_PS 8957 and ED_LPA 8957). This course provides a practical introduction to qualitative research and its applications in education and social sciences.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: The Supervision of Student Teaching-Masters
courses.description: Theory, knowledge and practices involved in supervision of student teaching and other professional lab experiences. Offers assistance in all major aspects of supervision of student teaching.

courses.name: Curriculum Theories
courses.description: Examines key ideological orientations in curriculum theory, explores the notion of curriculum as more than "a course of study" or "structured knowledge," and asserts that curriculum is embedded within historical discourses and practices of race, class, gender and sexuality. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Theories of Learning and Implications for Education
courses.description: The course will familiarize students with the learning theories most widely drawn upon in educational research. Students will examine how theories are used and the range of interpretations of these theories. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Philosophical Perspectives in Education Research
courses.description: An examination of the history and philosophy of social science research, including perspectives on ontology, epistemology, and axiology. Students will consider how various philosophical assumptions shape research paradigms, purposes, interests, and methodologies. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teacher Education Research
courses.description: This course is designed to prepare doctoral students as researchers who understand current trends and challenges for teacher education across the professional continuum, and who have the ability to formulate, compare, and problematize relevant research in the field.

courses.name: Research in Curriculum and Instruction
courses.description: Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Qualitative Methods in Educational Research II
courses.description: (same as ED_LPA 9620 and ESC_PS 9620). This course constructs a conceptual and methodological bridge between the understandings of qualitative research developed in Qualitative Methods I and more advanced study of theories, designs, and methods. The focus is on theory, approaches to data analysis, and interpretation. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Doctoral Research Seminar in Art Education
courses.description: This course focuses on art education research and is designed to offer doctoral students an opportunity to investigate, through readings, reflective thinking, writing, and discussion, the issues that impact art education research. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: The Supervision of Student Teaching-Doctoral
courses.description: Theory, knowledge and practices involved in supervision of student teaching and other professional lab experiences. Offers assistance in all major aspects of supervision of student teaching.
